thread.title: Free-runner Chase Armitage defies gravity to 'engage' with priceless art
thread.title_full: Free-runner Chase Armitage defies gravity to 'engage' with priceless art | Daily Mail Online

author: Jake Polden For Mailonline
title: Free-runner Chase Armitage defies gravity to 'engage' with priceless art
text:
15 shares 1
View
comments
A professional free-runner was invited to jump on and over priceless pieces of art to celebrate Sotheby's tenth annual sculpture exhibition.
Chase Armitage mounted and performed a handstand on the top of Barbara Hepworth's Three Obliques: Walk In before charging down Richard Long's Cornwall Slate Line.
This year the exhibition at Chatsworth House, entitled Beyond Limits, is themed and will showcase the landscape of post-war British sculpture.
Chase Armitage performed a handstand on the top of Barbara Hepworth's Three Obliques: Walk In
The free-runner was invited to jump on and over art to celebrate Sotheby's tenth annual sculpture exhibition
High-profile curator and artistic director at the Royal Academy, Tim Marlow, was brought in for the occasion and assembled the art alongside Sotheby's own specialist, Simon Stock.
Speaking to MailOnline ahead of the exhibition, which runs from September 14 to October 25, Mr Stock explained the idea behind advertising the show with a free-runner engaging with the art.
 The incredible cover of Whitney Houston's I Will Always Love... 'Move your lazy butt!' Hilarious moment stroppy cat Trick... He's no southpaw! Watch as Arne the dog throws punches at a... UF-NO! Strange blue lights appear over Florida prompting... 15 shares He said: 'Sculpture is not like painting, it's a 3D experience. It's designed to be walked, around, in, on and through, and when you turn around it takes on a different meaning.
'With Barbara Hepworth there is an invitation to walk into the sculpture. She wants her sculpture to be engaged with.
Tim Marlow was brought in for the event and assembled sculptures with Sotheby's art specialist Simon Stock
'Richard long invites you to walk over his work and participate in the same journey he took to collect the stones for his piece.
'And with the Conrad Shawcross piece (The Dappled Light of the Sun) the sun casts shadows onto the ground and you walk in and out of them.'
Prior to the video, robust sculptures were carefully chosen by the team to ensure that there were no accidents incurred during filming and that the pieces could withstand the great outdoors.
Mr Stock said: 'We selected appropriate sculptures. There are some that you wouldn't want to be touching day in day out.
Mr Armitage, the athlete featured in the video, is a stunt performer who has featured in a number of British films and television programmes
'It was strictly controlled and I was present at all times. These sculptures are out in the elements for the exhibition and exposed to rain and light, so he (the free-runner) had no impact on them.'
Mr Armitage, the athlete featured in the video, is a stunt performer who has featured in a number of British films and television programmes.
The 30-year-old's biggest role came in 2010 when he was cast as a Snatcher in Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1.
Mr Stock explained that the team selected appropriate sculptures that could withstand the elements before the free-runner climbed on and jumped from them
Mr Stock said: 'The man was a professional and awesome to watch. I don't know how he pulled it off was extraordinary.'
Among the work that will feature at this year's exhibition is Anthony Gormley's Big Gauge II, which has been placed among the rockery at Chatsworth.
Damian Hirst's Saint Bartholomew, Exquisite Pain will also be on display alongside Florian, a huge silver courgette sculpture by Sarah Lucas.
Mr Stock explained that sculpture is an engaging art form, which was why a free-runner was picked to advertise the exhibiton
And Barbara Hepworth's Sea Form, which Mr Stock explained was his personal favourite.
The curator concluded: 'There is a lovely broad range of art on display; sculptures that reaffirm the British tradition of post-war sculpture.
'The exhibition is a great place to see materials and colours from different artists of different periods.'
This year the exhibition at Chatsworth House, entitled Beyond Limits, is themed and will showcase the landscape of post-war British sculpture
